topics.body:
I'm going to bitch here for a second, but good god does the news repackage old news.

*click*
"Nasa investigating asteroid"
"Uhh. . no shit sherlock"
"Evidence of water on mars"
"How old is this news exactly?"
"Blackhole found at the center of the galaxy"
"OH MY FUCKING GOD!  HOW OLD IS THIS NEWS?!"

Does 24/7 news run on a year+ lag cause that's how long it takes for them understand things?  I mean holy shit; we have scientists printing organs and their idea of "news" is to repackage something we've known about for how long again?  Two decades I think?

Tl:dr; how is 20 year old events "news" again?
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5548215f6368720e5ee11000#post_5548215f6368720e5ee11000
Until they discover an alien species, NASA news is old news.

topics.body:
"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554821c663687227eb2a0a00#post_554821c663687227eb2a0a00
Call me crazy, but I have a feeling the reason for this is because new reporters don't understand science so they rehash it constantly until something they can understand comes along.

Look at when the Higgs Boson was discovered; it was a extremely important discovery, but since the news didn't understand why it was important they made themselves look like idiots trying to explain how it would impact society.
